page.title: 02CLEVELAND HILLS, S. BAYSDALE
page.content: A sparsely-populated area on the western edge of the North York Moors bissected by a N/S valley, lined with fir trees. A road gives access to the farms at the northernmost end of the area, and a number of public footpaths climb to the high points and follow the ridge. The heather moors are burnt periodically to provide the right conditions for grouse breeding and the lines of grouse butts provide welcome shelter in inclement weather for the sheep which graze on the moors. Walkers on the Cleveland Way find the views northwards to Teesside and westwards to the Pennines worth the battle against the strong winds. Leaving the paths, a feast of bilberries can reward the more energetic on the steep western flanks. From the eastern edge of the area, the valley of Westerdale can be viewed.
